title: Hull set to become ‘one of most exciting cities in Europe’ with £1,500,000,000 plan
text:
The project could turn the east East Yorkshire city into ‘one of the most exciting waterfront cities in the world’ (Lagoon Hull/PA Wire)

The city of Hull is set to lose it’s title as one of the most depressing cities in the UK to one of the most exciting waterfront cities in Europe.

Plans have been drawn up for a lagoon that would not just protect the city from flooding, but turn it into a major hub, creating thousands of jobs.

Computer-generated images reveal what £1.5billion of investment could look like with ‘waterfront living’ and a new highway to ease congestion in the city centre.

If given the go-ahead the project could provide around 14,000 new jobs in construction and for the new port facilities that would be built there.

Local MP Karl Turner said: ‘Lagoon Hull is the biggest, most ambitious project to have ever been devised in Hull and East Yorkshire. If realised, it is truly a game-changer for our region.

The project would build a seven-mile relief road along the Humber Estuary (Lagoon Hull/PA Wire)

This is what Hull currently looks like, giving an impression of the scale of the proposed project (Picture: Google Maps)

‘Crucially, Lagoon Hull will protect people living and working in East Hull and across the region from coastal flooding and the worst effects of climate change.’

A University of Hull study suggested that such a lagoon could have provided Hull with 100% protection during the 2013 tidal surge which flooded hundreds of homes.

Those running the project are hoping to ‘attract existing Government spending commitments’ and say the cost could be met through public and private investment.

Emma Hardy, Labour MP for Hull West and Hessle, said the development ‘delivers on so much of what this region needs and will have a long-term impact far beyond the immediate flood prevention’.

Humber Local Enterprise chairman Lord Haskins said the Humber region could be a ‘shining example’ of a city adapting to a changing natural, economic and cultural world.

The plan could bring up to 14,000 new jobs to the city (Lagoon Hull/PA Wire)

The lagoon would provide Hull would much better flood protection (Lagoon Hull/PA Wire)

He added: ‘The Lagoon Hull project would not just set the scene for the next century of investment and development in the region, it would make Hull one of the most exciting waterfront cities in Europe, possibly even the world.’

After three years of research, the team is looking get support for a five to 10 year feasibility work for the project and say building the actual lagoon would take another five years.

The idea is the brainchild of businessman Tim Rix.

He said: ‘The Lagoon Hull project is a once-in-a-generation opportunity to transform the future of the region.

‘It addresses the key challenges of today and unlocks our region’s potential for future economic growth, for place-making and creating a city and region where not only will young people want to stay and build their lives, but that attracts new and talented people to live and work.’

description: An 'ambitious' project of creating an artificial lagoon in Hull could change the character of the city and protect from flooding.
